Early Access Review
								Currently, Eden Star is a game with some incredibly amusing concepts, great visuals and suprising amounts of polish considering its an Early Access tittle still being in early alpha. Currently, the main aspect of the game is building and protecting a base in a tower defense esque setting. Starting out, you will spawn in a pretty small world of floating isles, having the ability to collect resources trying to set up a small base before the first night. You do so using a system reminiscent of Rust or Ark: Survival Evolved which is quite well implemented in this game. You will be able to roam the world using the suprisingly competent parkour movement, avoiding being mauled by enemies roaming the world. On your travels you will be able to harvest resources that can be used to build up your base and craft new gear for your character. Af it stands, the content that is there is fairly solid and is quite well implemented with some nice modeling and animations on your enemies, very simple to understand buildign and material mechanics and simplified crafting systems making the mechanic a fun method of progressing rather than a tedious bore. This is however where the good things about the game end as the amount of content currently avaiable is rather slim. Yes, there is a fairly nice variety of resources and structures you can build to defend your self from the incoming enemies, however you will find that the enemy variety it self is limited to a few monsters. The amount of things to do simply seems too small for the amount of time the game expects you to spend preparing for enemy attacks. Yes you can build up your defences, however I found that the amount of enemies that attack you at night is not big enough to pose a threat and while it might increase slowly over time, I found that its too slow allowing you to greatly outmatch the upcoming waves removing challenge from the equation. To summarise, while the amount of content is fairly small, the quality of the content that is there is mostly outstanding. This game has a lot of potential, with the quality of the content thats there, I am having no doubpts about this game becoming something great. If you don't mind the lack of features, I'd say give it a go and see if you enjoy it your self.

								This game is a mix between first-person shooter, tower-defense, and sandbox-survival. This game is Minecaft with a Sanctum twist.The game is as visually pleasing as it is fluid in movement. You have the parkour abilities necessary to climb almost anything, which makes the game a whole lot more interesting. You can wall-run and shoot down aliens that are attacking you and your base. The game is also very physics oriented which means destroying something from the base topples the entire structure.So far I have only seen 3 aliens, but there might be more, since the game seems to be infinitely-generated. There are 2 weapons for the player to use, a pistol (which you start with) and an assault rifle. As for defending your 'Eden Kit' (which is your life-support), you can craft 4 (or 5, I can't remember) defensive structures. The game also has basic parts for making a base. On that note, building in this game works very well, I was able to adjust the orientation of everything I placed to whatever I needed.From what I have read on the forums' this dev-team only releases updates when they are certain it is as far developed as possible, which makes for a far better play experience compared to indie titles that release buggier updates and simply fix them over time.All-in-all this is an incredible title, all it is missing (in my opinion) is a multiplayer, which would make this one of my top 10 favorite games. I definitely recommend buying, and playing, this game!

Early Access Review
								At the time of writing, In its current state. I would not recommend this game, which was not an easy decision despite my comments below.The premise of the game is:Mine minerals and construct a base on an alien world and build defences to fend of waves of enemies at night. Though when I say that, I by no means am condemning the game on its premise. There are some fantastic games in the genre, but also an awful lot of rubber-stamp garbage. At this point, I feel games that are attempting the Open World Survival genre, really need a new and captivating twist to keep players interested or invested, which this game just doesn’t have in its current state. However the developers list the game as "Action, Adventure" so perhaps the game is to be taken in a different direction? There is something about the game that seems deeply appealing, but currently, it’s buried under a lot of less appealing mechanics. The objective, at the time of writing, seems to be to upgrade your base core and see how long you can survive, which is what I was trying to do.Without further ado, the problems:The difficulty needs significant balancing. It’s chronically unforgiving to new players. After having difficulty, the first time playing, I rushed to build a base with 5 turrets and it was still taken out by night 5 by multiple waves of 10-20 flying enemies. There’s no time to relax and it’s horribly frustrating.Some people say mining is fast, some say it’s slow. My feeling is that you have to do such an overwhelming amount of it, it gradually feels slower the more you play because you’re sick of the grind. It feels very “No Mans Sky” in the way that mining is done. At the start of the game you can actually increase the mining speed, which is a good option to have for those that dislike the grind.  Apparently, there’s lots to explore. The map seems large initially, but even after a few hours of play relatively empty. There is not enough variety in map at present. Some areas look wonderfully pretty however. I did not play long enough to fully explore areas that looked potentially interesting in the far-flung corners of the map. Enemies are often seemingly spawned out of nowhere, often in large quantities suddenly and without warning and very close to the player’s location. In one situation, I looked away from my base for a brief moment, upon looking back there was a giant passive creature stuck inside it. I lost all my stuff after 2 hours of play to an enemy base, thinking it was friendly because of the blue shield/beacon (Enemy nests project a red beacon) I couldn’t retrieve my stuff because the turrets would kill me on approach. I figured I could trick the enemies into taking out the enemy base by sitting near it at night, but it turns out waves of enemies only attack your own base.The game explains nothing to you, except how to build, and how to repair. Everything else you have to figure out on your own, if you manage to survive the tutorial. Some people may like this, but unless the difficulty curve is tweaked, its only going to frustrate more people. All that said, this game has some serious potential. What it needs is decent base and player progression, something bright and shiny to aim for with a gradual difficulty curve.Currently the meat of this game is missing, it feels wrong to call it bare-bones, because there is a lot there, but it lacks depth. Which is why I had to have a serious think about recommending this or not. The game is very pretty and it plays very smoothly, but it doesn’t get off the hook because it’s early access. Early access does however, make me overlook the bugs and graphical glitches I came across. My recommendation is to save your money and watch its development with bated breath. The developers are along the right path, and if things continue as they are, the game will become something truly worth playing.

								Below you'll find a video and written impression on the game


YouTube™ Video: Eden Star: Early Impressions (Indie game survival crafting gameplay and review) 

			Views: 18,846		

			Eden Star: Early Impressions Eden Star video created on version: 0.0.1.9005 Eden Star is advertised as a survival space crafting game.		

Eden Star is a high fidelity crafting survival game with a sci-fi spin. You'll be tossed into an alien planet, gathering resources to craft defenses for your base, as during the night you could potentially get swamped by waves of enemies. Besides the danger of facing hoards of mobs, you'll also be exposed to toxic air, as the atmosphere of the planet turns toxic when the sun sets.Though the game states that it's a survival game, from my experience I feel that it's not a "true" survival game. There's no hunger, or thirst meter, and you don't go around the map collecting scattered objects. Every thing you need is all crafted. I would compare Eden Star to Minecraft much more than DayZ. I think when the devs mentioned survival they were referring to the base defense aspect, and perhaps the toxic air during the nights. The flow of the game is this: During the day you'll explore the map, gathering as much materials as possible, and when night falls you'll be under the protection of your base from the toxic air, while crafting defensive items, such as walls, weapons, and sentries to help you defend, that's if you're lucky to get a night where you're not hounded by waves of enemies. If that is the case, you'll probably be spending the night fending off mobs and making repairs.In it's current state, Eden Star is very playable, with enough features and functions for the player to explore, and it's also quite stable with out any crashes and a mostly consistent frame rate. But, being in early access, at the point of this impression the game does lack an "end game". Once you have every thing you need crafted with a well fortified base, there's not really much more to do. Couple this with the game's lack of save function, the player may lose interest much sooner than the game intends.The game looks good overall, using the unreal4 engine and does a good job at conveying the alien landscape. I don't have much complaints about the games visuals, though a more robust options with better graphic settings would be welcomed.Overall, Eden Star looks like it has a lot of potential with an interesting premise for a crafting game. I would love to see the game live up to it's "survival" description a little more, but here's hoping in future patches, we'll see more of that aspect come to light. It's an intriguing entry into the genre, and at the very least, worth keeping an eye on. Impression written on version: 0.0.1.9005Pros:- Good looking landscape- Base defense is a lot of fun- Good crafting system- Playable and stableCons:- Lacks content and an "end game"- I don't feel like it lives up to the "survival" description currently- underwhelming options menu

Early Access Review
								Eden Star is another open world, survival and crafting game available in early access on Steam. But what separates it from the all the rest that are vying for your hard-earned money are some nice twists, a unique combat system, and a futurisitc sci-fi setting. (okay, GRAV has that last one but BitMonster,Inc really dropped the ball with their futuristic survival game)It’s worth noting at this point that Eden Star is in a very early alpha state and that there is a LOT of content that needs to be added. At the moment I’d say that there’s about 2-4 hours worth of gameplay (depending how much you like base building). But even in its current state it's good fun, it has a solid gameplay foundation, and has a vast amount of potential. Moreover, the devs seem genuinely passionate about their creation, are continually keeping us updated with their plans and their progress, and are very good at replying to comments in the forums. So, Eden Star has a unique combat system that involves grabbing enemies with your telekinetic device and then throwing them in a chosen direction. This brings no end of fun, as you can launch them soaring up high into the air only to have them plummet and splat back onto the ground several moments later (okay, the devs haven’t added a nice squishy “splat” yet). After grabbing you can also quickly turn around and cast individual aliens off a cliff and watch them disappear down into the misty abyss below, or (and my personal favourite) you can grab one alien bug and use it to smash another one in a truly delightful process that hasn’t ceased to amuse me.In addition to the grab and smash approach, your equipment has an energy blast weapon that does exactly what it says to the alien creatures. This can be upgraded through unlocks to increase the power and duration of the blast so that it becomes a concentrated beam of searing energy. Thus adding another unique feature to this genre.The final part of (the current) combat are the more traditional weapons (currently just a pistol and an assault rifle), which help to complete the FPS aspect of the game. (There’s a rather nice looking sniper rifle on the Eden Star drawing board, and there are plans for grenades too)Harvesting resources is an essential part of the survival genre, and here Eden Star provides another variation on the theme. Instead of hacking away at rocks and trees with hammers and axes you use your energy harness tool to disintegrate and extract materials from their surroundings. Large rock formations slowly fall to pieces as the “tractor beam” wrenches them out of place and into your inventory.It’s actually quite satisfying to watch a tree crumble under gravity and disintegrate in front of you as you harvest the materials and energy from it with your high-tech resource gathering tool. What makes this even greater is that you can upgrade this, as well, to make harvesting faster and also to allow you to perform it from a greater distance from the target material. I really do love the unlockable and upgradeable features they’ve included so far.An interesting twist to the genre appears upon nightfall. Whereas Savage Lands brings a terribly bitter cold that forces you to seek shelter and huddle around a campfire to which you cling for dear life, and The Forest plunges you into true pitch black conditions in a hostile woodland, Eden Star brings something new to the table. As well as an increase in enemy activity (this is when you’ll be doing the most of your tower defence of your base) night time brings a potentially lethal exposure to radiation that compels you to withdraw and find refuge under the protective umbrella of your base’s energy shield. Keep an eye on the planet’s local time because you will need to get back to safety before you become fatally irradiated and/or before the hostile indigenous life rips your base to shreds.Very briefly, the base building is excellent so far and seems to be a futuristic version of Rust. Eden Star allows you to build floors, walls, and ceilings separately so that you can construct your base exactly how you want it. No prefabricated rooms or buildings that constrict your creative freedom here!Obviously, because this is still very early access I will be updating this review in the future after the devs have released significant updates. But for the time being I’m giving Eden Star a definite thumbs up!Things I would like/need to see developed for the final game include:- More action. Many more hostile life forms that are more threatening, thus deepening the FPS and tower defence aspects of the game to develop it into a true survival experience. The world is a little tame at the moment.- More types of defence towers and the addition of traps to defend your base during the night time attacks.- More fauna. Hostile, neutral, and friendly to enhance the feeling of the environment and the immersive atmosphere.- More geological feature. E.g. caves, water systems, impassable cliffs, geothermal pits, volcanoes - again to improve the environment further and to provide some unique locations for exploration.- Some sort of story and quests (i.e. an end game scenario). E.g. destroy all enemy life to make the planet habitable for your race to colonise. Or survive long enough to build a shuttle to escape from the hostile world on which you’ve been stranded. These are just my ideas.*** 21st December 2015 Update ***- A new energy blade melee weapon (that's rather reminiscent of Star War's light sabres). This is really good fun to use, it sounds absolutely fantastic (although quite a few ingame sounds are still buggy), and it really adds to the futuristic setting of Eden Star.- Two new enemies, the best of which is a particularly agressive flying creature that will suicide bomb attack your eden kit if you're not careful. It'll also dive attack you as well, knocking you back quite a distance. This can easily push you outside the shield of your eden kit thereby exposing you to the lethal night time radiation, or even worse, can propel you off a cliff to instant death. Be careful how you fight them!- Multiplayer!!! Both coop and PvP!For more information on current progress and future plans, check out what the devs post on trello.com, and as always leave questions here and I'll get back to you.Happy surviving, and remember: if you do die, be sure to clean up the mess please.

Early Access Review
Edited: This is one of the most helpful reviews on the page, so I cleaned it up a bit and added more stuff.Eden Star is one of those few early access titles that I've bought into. I generally stay away from them, apart from a few exceptions, and Eden Star is one of them. It caught my eye as a survival game with more of a base-building/tower defence focus, in which you gather resources and build your base and defences during the day, and defend it during the night. You start off with an Eden Kit and some resources, and you have until night to find a decent spot for your base. The base-building is quite versatile, and as long as you have the resources, you can create the base that you want to properly defend your Eden Kit. The Eden Kit is what protects you from this planet's toxic night air. If you go outside it's protective shield (which can be upgraded to increase it's radius) at night time, you start taking damage, and will eventually die. This makes defending it a top priority, and since the creatures that inhabit this world have taken a personal offence to your giant shield, defend it you must, as they will attack in swarms at night.This of course means combat, and it starts off as fairly standard, with a variety of guns and a melee weapon in case you run out of ammo. However, some upgrades to your MATA tool (essentially it's what allows you to harvest, build, etc), and you can basically become a jedi with an energy sword, and the ability to push and grab enemies and hurl them at whatever you want (this can also be chained, provided you don't hurl them outside grabbing range). Now, they may be cool to watch and everything, but they're just a gimmick right? Just shooting enemies is surely a lot easier? Well, in short, no. First off, the grab ability (the most useful and fun to watch) is tied in with your MATA tool's harvesting, so you don't have to bother switching to your gun. So depending on what you're pointing the reticle at, you can either harvest or kill. It's more of a convenience thing, but one I like. The second (and more important) benefit is that it saves on inventory space. Ammo for guns takes up inventory slots, so the more ammo you bring along for your trip, the less space you have to carry the resources you need.This means the non-gun options actually provide a tangible benefit to using them, since they don't require the ammo that guns do (although the push does require energy, but that is something completely separate and doesn't take up inventory space). And apart from all that, it's hilarious to grab an enemy, smash him into a rock, then fling him up into the sky.Right now, it is fairly light on content, and as you'd expect of an early access game, there are some bugs, glitches and crashes (although I personally haven't had a single crash), and I can always tell when a horde of enemies is about to attack my base at night, since the framerate dips fairly noticeably. However, I do have to say, the devs are doing a fantastic job with this game. They're passionate and dedicated, and I have no doubt they'll make this game the best they possibly can. They're incredibly transparent, regularly posting updates on what they're working on, and the vast majority of forum posts are answered by them personally. Ultimately, this is what convinced me to buy Eden Star, and if you like the concept and the direction of this game, you should too.

								To say that there are a fair number of "crafting survival" games these days would be a dramatic understatement. It seems like nary a week goes by without a handful more hitting Steam, let alone other platforms. And yet, Eden Star is proof positive that there is still a lot of room for different, novel ideas to take root in a genre becoming increasingly crowded.It's highly likely that you've played this kind of game a thousand times before now. Start with nothing. Forage stuff. Build stuff. Survive the night. Forage better stuff. Survive the increasingly difficult nights. And so on. The basic gameplay loop hasn't fundamentally changed from what Minecraft established years ago.Where Eden Star differentiates itself is two fold: one, its sci fi skin actually proves to be pretty compelling, as both the bases, defences, and weaponry you have at your disposal genuinely feel rewarding. There's inklings of Mass Effect and Deus Ex here in everything from the weapon design to the way the "magic" feels. The core gameplay here is rock solid.More importantly, though, Eden Star differentiates itself by way of its developers. Early access games are hard to get right, and Eden Star is helmed by a crew who is deadset on staying active in the community. The Trello Board is updated frequently, and the communicativeness of their planning and execution makes this one Early Access title you shouldn't be afraid of. Plus, having just patched in an entire multiplayer mode right before the holidays, it's clear the crew is dedicated to their game.Ultimately, though, both of these differentiating factors wouldn't matter if the game wasn't fun to play, and it is. More content will only help Eden Star become an even better, more widely adopted and successful game than it already is. Here's to that future success.

								March 12, 2016 - Pre-AlphaTLDRPros+Beautiful Environment+Smooth, flexible character mobility+Simple gathering system+Build a base, defend at nightCons-Combat feels unsatisfying-Extremely limited base building options-No sense of progression (resources / monsters)VerdictWhile the simplicity of it all is satisfying at first, you'll soon wonder what on earth you'll do next to keep things interesting.Full ReviewAfter over a year in Early Access, I expected more.I played the game for an hour, built everything there was to build, and tasted a few nights of combat. Some people are giggly wiggly over the fact that you can grab the monsters from afar and toss them around; I feel that overall, combat just isn't satisfying. Your weapons feel like crap; when you hit something, it'd be nice to have some feedback / recoil / monster recoiling / Something! Even the meelee doesn't work so well; half the time, you will automatically target a dead monster instead of the live one right next to it. What irks me even more is that monsters have no loot, in a world full of things to be looted.Indeed, if combat isn't so great, this type of game often falls back on creativity via building stuff, and exploration. I found however, that I could build everything right away! The resources aren't hard to find, or challenging to get; there's no sense of progression. I can't venture to a more dangerous area to retrieve a rare material to build a cooler turret to defend against a stronger monster. I can't discover more advanced tools or machines for my base, to fill it up with; I can just build a bigger base to fill up with a maximum of 3 types of turrets - and there isn't even an explanation of what differentiates them from one another.I really wanted to love this game, and was excited to play it, but after an hour, all that's left to do is build more iron foundations and walls, more of the 1 model power generator, more eden kits, more of the same 3 turrets, and watch it all take down more monsters at night. Inevitably, I will fall off another cliff along the way, or die inexplicably outside my front door, and lose all my gathered materials again.Perhaps in another year the game will be more fleshed out and start to resemble a final product; for now, all that can be done is play around with the mechanics.

Early Access Review
								Great game, but have a hard time recommending it in it's current state. It's the risk of early access, I suppose, but still.- The premise:You're an advanced colonial super ninja type engineer cyborg dude in some sweet♥♥♥♥♥futuristic battle garments. Your left arm has a powerful piston powered baton spear thing (that would make a mean plot device in some weird Japanese sex game, but I digress) and your right arm has some device that can eat trees and rocks. There's currently no story, but the context more or less lets you know that you crashed landed on a strange environment, from an espace pad. The environment is abundant and has alien fauna and flora. You use the right hand device to deconstruct and "consume" and store elements from those objects. Different objects offer different elements.Those elements can be used to construct an "Eden Star" which is some sort of colonization kit that is the heart of your base. Around this base, there's a wide array of componets to build with. Basic things like foundation blocks, walls, doors, panels, but also turrets, laser fences, etc. Building anything use a block-like system where you snap-and-click different componenets together. Here's why I like this game so much: it takes the free-roam, sandbox games and gives you a clear purpose: gather, build and DEFEND. I love sandbox games, but their achilles heel is that they tend to be pointless: you gather, build and... then what?Eden Star on the other hand, offers a very solid narrative in that there's a day-night cycle. During the day, local alien goons are fairly inactive and will only pursue you if you get too close to their hives (ie.: destructable spawn points). During the night, however, they get the alien munchies and somehow have a taste for your Eden Kit. In other words, in a true open-world fashion they will flock to your base in numbers and it's up to you to defend it. This causes you to explore, harvest and build during the day, so you can defend your base at night. At some points, you're really minding the clock so you can manage your time in harvesting, building and defending. You, the player, can craft weapons and items that can be equipped, or you can upgrade your gear. For example, the right hand tool that is used to deconstruct the local fauna and flora, can be upgraded to become a gravity type weapon: lock on to a baddy, grab it in a gravity type field and just launch it into space, smash it against and object or my favorite: fling it at another alien. It's oddly satisfying.The Eden Kit can also be upgraded with a better shield and offers a few neat little tricks itself.- Gameplay:It's pretty nice. The mechanics are easy to use, the harvesting, combat and building aspect felt solid and fluid to me. The harvesting is fairly balanced, in that it does NOT get grindy. You do not need to take down an entire forest worth of trees to build a single block. Inventory management is also easy and hassle-free. You can focus on building, crafting, exploring, adventuring and defending. Going through the different categories and building materials can be a tad confusing.Game offers a solid single player experience and has added a multiplayer aspect not too long ago. Multiplayer needs some work, griefing is there but it's just not that easy to run up to another player's base and not get torn to shreds. Thus far, the player community has been helpful and non intrusive. Sure, I've been chased around by some random dude who really wanted to fist me with his left-hand-piston-power-spear-baton♥♥♥♥♥♥♥contraption, but I've also set up bases with random strangers I encountered. - Graphics:Noting extraordinairy, but nothing poor either. Everything feels well executed. Performance is also agreeable, game loads fast. Level design is actually pretty cool. The setting is no planet, but a series of giant, floating rocks. The terrain is diverse. Monsters currently feel a bit silly and stiff. Nothing at all threatening, as you can just bolt out of there with your infinite stamina colonial cyborg ninja. Did I mention you look pretty sweet? You look pretty ♥♥♥♥ing sweet. - Sound:A bit lacking as of yet. Nothing that really garners your attention. Currently, there are no missing sound clips and I suppose the devs are focussing on the core game.- Stability:Alas, this is my biggest gripe with Eden Star: Single player crashes to desktop one too many times. Multiplayer offers dedicated servers that appear and disappear at the blink of an eyes. Especially frustrating if you chanced upon a helpful stranger and were setting up a base... only to be dc'ed and can no longer find the server. I hope the devs take their time to increase this. At the moment, I've stopped playing Eden Star, because there is no point in investing any time in a single or multiplay session, your work is lost all too easily. A damn shame, because I honestly, believe this game really deserves a lot more credit.- The devs:These guys are really going for it. If you follow their updates, you cannot dislike them. They're very enthusiastic and they seem to listen to their community. I haven't been all that involved myself, so I might be off. The only thing I do want to say, is that I like seeing information on updates - ACTUAL GAME UPDATES.Never thought I'd say this about an indie dev, but these guys overdeliver on information. They share updates on... updates. That are to be released weeks later. It's fun, guys and I dig the spirit, but maybe you should keep those posts on the forum or something. Anyway, I'll be checking in on those game more often.- The conclusion:Buy it, try it, support the devs, enjoy a refreshing take on open-world sandbox games that offer a DECENT narrative and a goal and if your fancy is tickled by tower defense games, this game is the perfect hybrid. Be wary about stability, though. Both single player and multiplayer are NOT crash free.

Early Access Review
								EDEN STAR is what you get when Rust/H1Z1/survival games have a beautiful baby with gems such as Lost Planet 2, Titanfall, and more.There are so many wonderful ideas. From base construction, crafting, to automated defenses and a meaningful day/night cycle. But it doesn't stop there. Wall running parkour, grappling/riding enemies, unique abilities, and they are working on automatons to help you fight entire wars against other player factions.The game is pre-alpha, but I would buy it again. The dev team posts updates practically weekly, and provide a level of transparency that is on par with or beyond even the famously open Star Citizen. They speak to us, and they have a personal relationship with the community. Unlike so many big corporations that follow strict PR guidelines, this is a group of people that know their audience, people who have soul, and most of all dedication: this is obviously a project of passion for everyone involved.That really does meaning something, because gamers as consumers really care about the brands they play. They do have a more personal relationship with the creators and company than other consumers do. A game isn't like flour: I don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the flour or who supplies it, so long as it isn't wood pulp and it's reasonably priced. But games are something I may spend hundreds to thousands of hours on. They are something people care about and grow to love. That's why gamers are notoriously fickle: because they're passionate. They want to see a game be everything that it can be, and they see the company and developers as *partners* in that endeavor. But most game companies have not caught on to this, and still treat it like any other customer-business relationshipBut not Flix Interactive. They understand the nature of their relationship with us. To have a game company actually listening and communicating is a breath of fresh air. There is no silence to make you nervous, there are no worries about if you're being heard or what's going on. You know. And they don't just talk to you. They listen. They take player feedback. For instance, players wanted to build huge bases, even cities. This was never planned for or intended. Do you know what they did? They began optimizing the game for accomodate large structures as best as they could. The idea for drones and fighting robots arose from this, and it's why they're developing it; it all came back to the players wanting large settlements, and those settlements needed defenders.With all that said, the game is a pre-alpha. Performance is not exceptional, though over the last patch it has improved immensely in my opinion. The movement is janky at times, the UI is kinda buggy now and then, and it has its mechanical problems. But that's how it goes with a pre-alpha.But as a cynical consumer, skeptical and disillusioned with a distant game industry stuffed with the same recycled material, this is a game that stands apart. This surely sounds like a contradiction, as the market is being flooded with survival games. Is this a survival game? Yes, absolutely. But it is not confined by that genre: it builds on it with great ideas. This is a game I can love with a dev team I can believe in.If you are something of a gaming philanthrophist, then let me say now: if there was ever a game that deserved your money, it is this one. If for whatever reason, you don't want to spend money on it in its current state, that's fair. But be sure to check back every few months. I don't think you'll be disappointed.If you want to see the future plans, what is being worked on at present, and what has been added, take a look at the trello board here: https://trello.com/b/dmyocCtO/eden-star-public-boardPlayers can vote on what they'd like to see added next, provide feedback, and provide ideas. The devs are also active on steam, and have a subreddit which at the moment is practically just updates and patch notes.

								A game with a lot of potential, currently still early in its development cycle... and it shows at times.THE UPSIDE:I was really drawn to the sort of 'mass effect' feel in a survival game.  Even the tool you use to mine, craft, build or fight reminded me of an 'omni-tool', as do the weapons.  Survival games are so frequently based around the sword and board ages or... gah... zombies, this game presented a much welcomed alternative to those flavors.The game looks beautiful and the mechanics seem well polished and in fairly good working order, particularly when you take the development point of the game into account.THE DOWNSIDE:There are two major problems with the game right now and both are likely to change as development continues... i hope.The first as i see it, the game is extremely shallow.  While everything you can do works well and looks pretty good, you can do just about all of it within a few hours of play.  You can always make your base larger and more elaborate and you can always farm for more materials, but beyond that survival is never really an issue after the first few turrets are placed down.  That isn't to say there isn't something enjoyable about building elaborate structures and seeing just how difficult you can make it for another player to get into your base, but right now you are pretty limited by type/number of things you can build.The second major flaw in the system right now, and really i can't stress this enough, the server system is an exercise in pure frustration.  As it stands right now, you join a server and maybe you even took the time to visit the forums and find out which servers are "most reliable".  Even among these your doing well if your server is up more than two or three days in a row without disappearing for that at least that long.  You can switch servers of course and restart your base again... and then you can do it again when this server vanishes... and again... and honestly if you do it again you kind of deserve what you get.Largely for this reason multiplayer is a pretty lonely existence.  Rarely more than 2-3 people are ever on the supposedly "most reliable" servers.  And its fairly easy to understand why.  One confusing mechanic was that while all servers are listed as PVE, they are most certainly not.  By accident my friends and I had found our way into another base and were shocked to find we were able to access their resources.  We actually were somewhat pleased at this revelation because while i'm not sure its intended it meant the game had radically new meaning.  We had to rebuild our base to defend against players!  And we were going to gear up and venture out and see what other bases we could crack.  This was quite a lot of fun, but then enter the extreme unreliability of the servers, to say nothing of the general confusion as to the PVE/PVP status of those servers.THE LOWDOWN:  6.0/10  *with a lot of potentialFor someone who doesn't usually look twice at survival games this one really caught my attention.  It has a lot going for it and i really hope the development process continues along the very promising lines it seems to be.  If your truly are looking for a single player survival experiences (WHY?) then a lot of the issues i have with the game really don't impact you, however, if your looking for a multiplayer experience or to play with friends, the game right now is just not ready.  Its one i will most certainly be keeping an eye on and very hopeful that i'll feel i can rightly flip this review.

Early Access Review
								This game is an interesting one. The whole thing revolves around a basic tower defense principal, where you build and protect your Eden Kit from hostile native species, because you're the invading alien and they don't like you. Beyond the possibility of some shoehorned social-political commentary or some such, this game is actually pretty good.The combat system is responsive and fun and you have to pay attention to pretty much every enemy so you don’t get pinned into a corner. The parkour system helps with this, allowing you to do a bit of guerilla warfare by running up with your Gauss Cannon, hitting a hive for a few seconds, before running back off into the trees and away from the hordes of enemies. You can and will augment your personal arsenal of firearms and energy weapons with turrets placed around your base to keep away the night time raids. The turrets are fairly basic, as there’s currently only 3 types, missile, auto (machine gun), and laser. You also have to manage power levels in your base, each turret takes some power, and each generator adds some power to the pool. I’m not terribly far in this game yet, so I’m not sure if there’s a practical limit on turrets.A big part of this game is the building system. As far as I know, your structures won’t collapse in Red factions style if you build them poorly (I hope that gets added in at some point) but if you’re not careful, you’ll eventually get a message telling you that you cannot place XYZ at that location because your structure is weak. This can get a bit annoying when trying to build a bridge, but I appreciate the realism. In order to build structures, you’ll need to strap on your big boy pants and venture out into the wilderness to collect resources. Each structure, as far as I know, can be built out of different base materials, depending on what you have or what you need. For example, an Ironite base is the strongest, but Ironite can be a bit annoying to come by, especially early in game if you don’t know where to look. So, instead of Ironite, you can build with Bridgmanite (no idea if I spelled that right) and take a slight dip in health to stock up on Ironite. Or, you may have a small Ironite structure protecting your Eden Kit, with a larger Bridgmenite fortification. Most weapons and modules can also be built from 2 or 3 base materials, which allows you to ration supplies more effectively.Storage is a big problem in this game. If there’s a storage container that isn’t your Eden Kit, I haven’t found it. The Eden Kit has 5 material storage slots, and each of those can hold a stack of 300 of one material. This is fine at first, until you’re going out and coming back with your inventory full, because you didn’t use all your bullets the previous night. Your character has an inventory of 10 slots, each able to hold a max of 300 of one raw material, much like the Eden Kit, the place where this gets a bit iffy, is that ammo only stacks to a certain amount, I think around 144 per slot (which sounds like a lot until you get mobbed by 20 enemies and you begin to fire wildly into the crowd).The last thing I want to say is just little things I like about the game. The physics in this game are amazing. Pretty much any material node can be deconstructed into physics particles (except for large boulders, which just fuzz out of existence if you try to cut them into smaller pieces). As you mine, collectable materials will spawn and then despawn as you absorb them. PSA though, don’t stand on top of what you’re mining, because there’s a rare chance that the game will flip its♥♥♥♥♥♥with the physics objects and launch you into the air. The environments, are beautiful, with each biome having different resource nodes that give you different materials. As far as I know, and I haven’t done any extensive exploration, the basic biomes are: Desert, Forest, and Swamp, with a nice blending where they border each other. Each biome will have its own sort of special resource nodes that will give you a specific material, so you’ll eventually need to branch out and explore to get a decent stockpile.So yeah, this game is pretty good so far, pretty solid gunplay, a decent parkour system, and it seems to have a lot of polish for an early access game. There isn’t a lot of depth to it yet, but I think I can see where they’ve left room to add that later, with time and more updates.

								(sorry for the quality of this review but I don't write reviews often)I bought this game last year (2015) and as you can see by the 3+ hours of game time , I don't play it much. Why would I recommend this game? I think this game is has lots of potential. I know everyone says that about all their games or games they like but the development team is adding things constantly to their early access game. Several times a month as far as I can see. I bought this game after reading up on the Unreal 4 engine, and after a free weekend playing Ark Survival evolved.I’ve always been a fan of Unreal 4 , this game shows it with great looking graphics, runs well for the hardware and small ~2GB game size is probably all due to Unreal 4.Did the game live up to my expectations after playing Ark Survival? No, but I genuienly believe that it will be just as good in the future. The game felt more like Minecraft Tower defense for a while since your base is attacked at night and you can’t venture too far away at first but this summer they started adding food requirements and expanding on actual survival elements. The parkour also feels really good, I enjoy running around and climbing stuff, or running along walls. That said, I haven’t encountered any bugs or glitches, which you’d normally find in an early access game. It’s also possible I just haven’t gotten far enough to see them.Anyway, if you like Sci-fi settings, feeling the pressure of keeping your base safe and of course gathering materials and building stuff  then I think you’ll enjoy this game.

Early Access Review
								As of v0.0.1, Eden Star has a tendency to crash on my system at the frequency of roughly 1 hour into the game, and there is no means to save, so there's no real persistence to my efforts as of yet.   Still, it's a pretty solid start to a really cool take to the whole construction-survival-sim.Core to the coolness of this game is how you are wearing a suit that lets you break down trees and rocks in a realistic fashion, they pop and break as you work, the power of a micro singularity at your fingertips, so you can scoop the matter up in some sort of matter digitizer and take it back to your Eden platform in order to build construction blocks, turrets, and weapons.  This suit can also be upgraded to become a full on grav gun, picking up and throwing enemies and other objects, as well as a rail gun upgrade.  It's a great platform to play with 3D engine physics, although it keeps everything above ground (no digging) and it's mostly just rocks and trees and aliens right now.Making progess involves upgrading your Eden platform by converting resources into energy but, the more energy your Eden platform has, the more attention of the hostile wildlife it attracts.  As there is nothing to do but upgrade your Eden platform, in theory, things will slowly but steadily ramp up from being a leisurely walk to a desperate fight to hold your ground.  In action, it's very barebones right now, the attacking wildlife comes in slowly, sometimes not at all and, just when things are starting to get interesting, the game crashes or locks up (your mileage may vary; my system might be less compatible than yours).  Lacking a means to save the game, I am sent back to the beginning.  But it is certainly a pretty interesting tech demo for as long as it lasts, and I hope the developers see through their vision instead of losing motivation, pocketing the early access money and running as some do.

								   Not sure if I've made a review for this yet... And I'm not exactly sure doing this at 6 in the morning, with no sleep at all, is the brightest of choices, but here I go.   What's a good way of describing Eden Star? Well... It's good. Like, really good. How it works is much different than any others like it. In fact, it confused me at first... Instead of knowing about wall running, and taking that first path towards the Eden kit, I went a long way around, and leaped off a cliff to get to it. Can something like minecraft, or the countless other Survival games do that? Maybe. But it more than likely won't make you seem like such a bad-a** while doing so.   Aside from that, there's no terrain deformation. All there is, is the ability to cut down trees, dig into various above-surface ore deposits (Which regenerate over time... Somehting that could be seen as unnerving), and go at the various "Hives" around the game area, in order to get the lovely rare as all hell resource that you use to respawn, upgrade equipment, and so on.   Where am I going with this? Not exactly sure, but I'm guessing that I'm doing pretty good so far. Anyways, the combat system is very unique... It's rare for a game to go "Here. Have fun." and give you access to an item that lets you throw things around like rag dolls. Sure, the targeting is a bit off... Making it hard to actually hit things that are close to you... But it's a fun and unique part of the game that adds that much more charm to it all.   And on the topic of charm... The design of the map is beautiful. And with the ability to run up and along walls for short distances makes it that much better. I can't tell you how long I spent climbing a single mountain, to "save some time", while exploring. Spoiler warning: It didn't. And I was attacked about halfway up. Without a gun. Fun, right?   But yeah, I haven't played the game lately, as... Even with all its charm, I have to admit, it can get a bit old after a while, in the stage it was at. But I would play this game over any other, any day of the week. Because really, it's fun, and I enjoy how different it is compared to other games. Sure, there are people out there who could play "Call of duty advanced Z nuke strike" and call it innovative in its rinse-wash-repeat design, and good on them. They found a game they like. But I'm thinking that they wouldn't enjoy this game too much... It'll just be too complicated for them. But yeah, you may like this game, or you may not. This is just my opinion on it, and if you don't like it, leave.

								So to start of. For a pre-alpha game it's very impressive.Concept: The concept is very interesting. At times feels like a fpswith some satisfying weapons (currently pistol, SMG, Rifle, Sniper, Baton, Energy Baton)and then feels like a 3D mine craft.The build system is very similar to fallout 4 in terms of snapping objects etc..but atm, as it is pre-alpha, doesnt have content (basic structural components, 3 types of turret and a few utilities, power gen etc..)FPS: FPS wise it's pretty solid having been built with Unreal Engine 4.Weapons have satisfying models and sounds and the enemies are varied enough torequire different tactics not just spamming rifle. You can also upgrade youmining tool to project kinetic blasts for knock back and through upgradesadd furhter knock-back, damage, projected laser etc.. to make combat muchmore varied. Feels sort of like a fantasy RPS with both guns and magicks.Enemies: There are a select few differnt types of enemies that spawn at certain sites, destroying the hive while enemies attack is challanging and rewarding (rare ore telirium?)On a night they attack your base and if you don't take care of the hive the attacksbecome worse, sustaining damage to walls,defenses and your EDEN kit.Movement: I really like the parkour in this game. Very satisfying to be acble to scale rock faces with the ability to actually reach ledges significatly higher than you.Mining: Mining is cool. Holding the right mouse strips ore deposits and trees with a nice context menu telling u the compisition of different minearls.THe mining can also be upgraded to either be faster, reach futher or enhance combat by paralysing enemies and then throwing them etc..Graphics: Very nice graphics as expected form unreal engine 4. Lighting is a bitodd for me (could just be me) but the light and dark areas can be too high contrast at times.However as pre-alpha this isn't something I would hold against the DEVS.Mulitplayer: Not done multiplayer yet but the devs have some pretty good looking guides for setting up a server. Upgrading and construction: The upgrades and construction require certain minerals/oresas a base cost and some allow you to choose the aditional ore/mineral. This allows you to play stategically in what ores/minerals you have to spare etc..basic structures like walls etc. can be made using a select few, some way more common than othersbut the rarer minerals/ores add bonuses / debuffs to HP heat resistance etc... which is a nicetouch. Equipment wise upgrades for your mining tool, kinetic force, repair tools requires both specific minerals/oresand additional. Ammo is made at the Eden Kit so you have to work for your ammo, again a nice touch.Development: The devs seem very pasionate about this game and what they've promisedto include looks like this game could become very popular. 								Sci-Fi Minecraft, which is great, and if the problems I am going to mention are eliminate, then this is a must have, but so far I think its a neutral with great potential. Mind you this is still in early access, so I can forgive the devs for some of the problems.The game features a pre designed world with multiple biomes fill with neutral and aggressive creatures. You need to build a base to survive the night, because during night, the atmosphere turns toxic and you are only protected from the toxicitity by your base. During day time you can gather materials and use it to build floors and walls, defence turrents, generators, or use it to craft upgrades, weapons, and ammo. The world is huge, but generic, which is disappointing, but never the less, still great.There are some crucial problems though - motion sickness. For a survival base-building game, it is a killer problem to have motion sickness, and although motion sickness may not apply to everyone, from my experience, it hurts my brain. In a survival base-building game, you expect players to grind and run all around the place for a long duration, and so motion sickness will accumulate and just hurt the player physically, which is just terrible. A suggestion from me will be adjust the audio, and also make sure when gathering materials, the debris don't fly into the camera. Soften the colorful effects for material gathering, the bright color flashing around hurts the eye.Pros:-Great survival building game, challenging, but not too punishing-Like Minecraft, has great potential in the building aspect-More combat than Minecraft-Turrets :)-Still just Early Access, and already amazing-Decent graphicsCons:-Minor bugs-Generic environment-Motion sickness (for me at least)-Expensive?-Would be better to have materials scattered after death, rather than have the player lose all their materials. 								UPDATE 8. October 2015: Still gonna give my thumbs up for this game, the new additions (more upgrades, a new biome, heavily improved building UI including new buildings, new enemy AI including perception and improved pathing, new foliage system that improves performance and makes forests more dense) make sense and the game still runs way too smooth for an alpha. No major crashes or freezes on my system, in all of my playtime the game crashed around 7 times through all updates. The development process is as transparent as ever (devs uploading designs and plans for basically everything except lore). My experience has been nothing but positive until now.Multiplayer is soon going to be added too, I am going to further update my review by then.game: 8.5/10 (not too much to do, but it's an alpha dammit), graphics 9/10, potential 17/10------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Eden Star is an early-access game with a sci-fi setting. It belongs to the genres of sandbox, ego-shooter and has roleplay elements. So, first off, this game is in a very early early state and most of the gameplay is not implemented, this review is based on the 0.04 pre-alpha update.I can only speak positive of this game so far, the stability is frightening for a game in a this early state, I only encountered 4 crashes so far and the FPS are stable (i7, 760gtx), the game runs on Unreal Engine 4. The graphics are really good, feel well composed and the art-style is appealing(imo).Now let's come to the gameplay aspect: Some upgrades are already in, 3 weapons and basic construction. Most of it feels well implemented, it just seems that the devs know exactly what they want, this is not some project of some unorganized garage-devs(*huh*starforge*huhhuhu*). Shooting is still a bit inaccurate. The cool thing is the power of UE4, resource mining feels really awesome and the world is really immersive. The fighting is based on shooting and using your tools like lifting enemies and samshing them into the ground, all paired with parcours elements and wallrunning.So, EDEN STAR has a lot of potential, but we still have to see how it will become but it definitely has better chances of becoming something. The devs are also very responsive and explain why they implement what.

								Starts out gathering resources, Looses base. Figures out I have a way of finding my base, goes out to explore and almost dies. Forgets I have a way to find base, wanders and gets lost, returns to base - night one begins. One enemy... I think this game is to ez pez. Night two, Army of xenos comes and I get rekt. 20/10 epic game, great building system so far and so much potentialUpdated Review 2/28/2016Now-  serious part of the review. (MANY MANY run on sentences)Seeing as, I don't have so many hours in this game - That doesn't make someone bad whatsoever. Eden-Star is that type of game where you arent judged by how good you are in hours put into the game, The game is relativley very easy to pick up, where the hours would only mean how large someones base could possibly be. In four hours, I have achieved most things (Some things i dont like to unlock) - this is not including weapons. This game is very free-to-do on your own basis, as in it has no meta.I'll break it down with some points on how free you are from many things.Combat System - With the combat system, in most games that involve survival, you'd have to use a "main" tier of weapon, primarily relying on a gun, or some sort of other system. In Eden-Star, you can obtain the Energy Blade relativley early (Basically a superbuffed version of a wrist baton) ; with the addon of automatic aim for melee, you have the capability of charging air enemies, and in basic, warp jumping and smashing them out of the sky (It's not a one hit kill most of the time). Including, you cant just sweep and expect to kill everything, the melee system is Voxel-Physics based, If i were to hit something they could possibly tumble and slightly damage other enemies around them, the blade slicing from the main enemy into the next one besides it. Not only this, due to the physics/voxel way of the game, you have the capability of shoving things down hills or off cliffs.(A quick note) RMD Modules -Laser hand! Be Iron-man!Use the force to litteraly smash explosive cysts onto your enemies, or smash them into walls, other enemies, throw them in the sky, etc! (Some enemies explode on death, though they have a start up timer to that, you can throw corpses away or into other enemies!)Gauss cannon! Because whatevers in your face is going to die.With guns, The different types of weapons you have in Eden-Star have the capability of using any of them as a main weapon, as they are all realistically powerful; though are able to be played for people with different playstyles, riflemen, bullet spazzing-smg players, or snipers.Building -Since the world is voxel based, If you play Space Engineers you can get a feel for how it all works. Though with that, you can mesh things together (Like in Medieval Engineers) ; If you play Ark Survival Evolved, you may also get this concept. If you place one foundation, you can place walls on all four sides, then on the outer part of those walls, and below into the floor covering the foundation itself (Sometimes you cant, as it runs into voxels which balances it; though for the most part you have very free basis to add even more armor to foundations with this feature). In short, if that confused you, One foundation can hold 12 walls (Which is very cheap) - leaving bases able to be very cheap to create. The game also has a bit of 'structural integrity', platforms only go so far without having a support beam under them (Which can be covered with eight walls on one platform) - as real physics dictates, if that beam breaks, you can be sure whatever ontop of it will go down with it - sadly you wont get the resources from whatever broke. Turrets are automated and for the stages of this game, GREATLY work. They cover a bit of angles, and don't fire directly into your base, or try to fire if somethings inside, breaking your own stuff. Not only this, Since the game is voxel based, you could have turrets wherever you want, they are not limited to platforms, or foundations. You can have half walls out on the fields as well, not limiting it to just platforms/foundations.- The only thing with building is that it can only get a certain extent from your EDEN-Kit (3x3 Square Core you need to protect, loosing this does not end the game) ; This ONLY applies to what i know, solid big mass buildings, you can freely place other foundations/EDEN Kits and whatnot inside/around your EDEN-Kit's bubble (Expandable). Not only this - Buildings, are VERY. VERY. Tough. (Since i use Ironite, very common)

								I have not played much yet, because I mostly went sandbox mode so I wouldn't get myself killed instantly. Some reviews here complain about the intro, but if you read the discussion forum you learn to switch to the experimental branch and to disable enemy spawn completely. Heck you can even turn damage off entirely, have not seen this many options in terms of AI in a game, means you can suit it exactly to your playstyle. Vehicles would probably also make a nice addition here, trying to get around the large game world can take some time, which is not a negative if you think about it.The base-building system, similar to the mining, takes a bit getting used to get things right where you want them, but it works and once you complete a large base I am sure it will look pretty cool.The fact multiplayer is already built in and continues to be improved is good to see, most games tend to neglect that part. I have not been able to test that yet, because it lacks a linux server version and somebody to play with :)Overall I can recommend this game, I played another space survival game the other day and had to refund that, cringed too hard at the mechanics, this was a refreshingly well made Early Access title and I can definitely see this beating some recently released AAA titles. Early Access Review
								Not worth the $20 I paid for the existing content.For $5, sure, its not a bad early access, but as it is there isnt near enough for me to feel like I didnt just waste my money.Maybe over the next year it will earn its price tag.What they have so far is in some ways solid. The graphics are decent enough and the effects look nice. Combat feels right. Traversing the landscape is fast and fun without the worries of many survival games such as eating, stamina, or realistic fall damage. The first thing I noticed that felt incomplete was a general lack of sound. No music, very little movement sound effects, and this crazy glowing thing on your hand that rips trees down and pulls boulders apart makes almost no sound at all. You only only hear the actual target getting shredded. Speaking of the harvesting/collecting, at its core it is fun. You can take out the bottom of a tree and watch it fall in various ways with nice physics and such.I know this is early access, so missing sounds and the only 2 extremely generic enemies I saw is understandable, but once you get the hang of the build system (took me about 20 minutes) you are just gathering, building a base with very limited options, watching/helping your turrets kill the 2 bad guy types, then rinse and repeat. The difficulty ramps up each night as you improve your base. You can save and try different approaces to getting through a night, and you can respawn if you have a certain ore on your base gained by destroying enemy nests. Die without any ore, game over, reload last save.I got base built up and had about all the fun there was to have in about 3 hours, and I can't say that fun was real exciting or special. This is another early access where I would wait and see whet the devs have in store for it instead of paying too much for a general draft of the game's basics. I do see potential though.

Early Access Review
								A bare bones and flawed game on a solid concept and design foundation. I've only spent on hour in the game so far on the day of initial E.A. release.  The controls are great as are the graphics.  But, right now, it doesn't really feel like a game per se.  You have about 6 minutes of daylight to run around and zap trees and rocks, then about 6 minutes of night to zap bugs.  The bugs seem to just warp in under my feet as well.  The daytime doesn't seem to be long enough to really dig into any kind of building or exploring and nighttime is a tower defense mini game.Some suggestions to what's currently in game (not additional features):Harvesting trees makes visual sense.  I can see the tree fall and break into pieces.  And they take a comfortable amount of time to do so.  Harvesting rocks is a visual mess and takes far longer.  Perhaps tightening up the visual clues of what's left in a rock to harvest or something to clue me into the progress would be helpful.  Also, since I only have abou 6 solid minutes of daylight, spending 2 of them on a rock is extremely limiting.The bug alien critters seem to just pop out of nowhere.  I'm not sure if that's a bug (no pun intended) or that's how they work.  It was odd to be turning around looking for these things and they just pop in under my feet.  Perhaps if they originated from their little dens or mounds and skittered toward me.They day/night cycle time is very rushed.  Right now, I feel like the game can't decide if it wants to be a exploration/construction game or a tower defense.  It has aspects of both, but they are hampered.  And one major way is the short time windows.  Let me explore and harvest a little longer and actually have some time to build something and maybe have some kind of build up at night, the pacing and number of bugs attacking increases or comes in waves instead of the static two pop in at a time in exact intervals.Overall, I think the presentation of the game is solid.  The help pop ups are clear and understandable.  The graphics are nice and the art direction has its own identity.  I think there's more foundation in this game than many E.A. games in terms of setting, design, and concept.  It certainly has a long way to go, and I'm excited to follow it as it develops.
